editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Lingua: OR THE COMBAT OF The Tongue, AND THE Five SENSES FOR SUPERIORITY. A pleaſant Comoedy.
London, Printed for Simon Miller, at the Starre in St Pauls Church-yard. 1657.

div.head: LINGUA. DRAMMATIS Perſonae.

list.item:
VISUS.
LUMEN.
COELUM.
TERRA.
HERALDRY.
COLOR.

div.p: The Scene is MICROCOSMUS in a Grove.
The Time, from Morning till night.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: OUr Muſe deſcribes no Lovers paſsion,
No wretched Father, no unthrifty Son:
No craving ſubtile Whore, or ſhameleſs Bawd,
Nor ſtubborn Clown, or daring Paraſite,
No lying Servant, or bold Sycophant.
We are not wanton, or Satyricall.
Theſe have their time and places fit, but we
Sad hours, and ſerious ſtudies, to reprive,
Have taught ſevere Phyloſophy to ſmile.
The Senſes raſh contentions we compoſe,
And give diſpleas'd ambitious TONGUE her due:
Here's all Judicious friends; accept what is not ill,
Who are not ſuch, let them do what they will.

stage.p: LINGUA, apparelled in a Crimſon Sattin gown, a Dreſſing of white Roſes, a little Skean tyed in a purple Skarf, a pair of red Buskins drawn with white Ribband, ſilk garters, gloves, &c.
AUDITUS, in a Garland of Bayes intermingled with red and white Roſes upon a falſe hayr, a cloath of Silver Mantle upon a pair of Sattin Baſes, wrought ſleeves, Buskins, Gloves, &c.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: NAy good Auditus do but hear me ſpeak.

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.l: Lingua thou ſtrik'ſt too much upon one ſtring,
Thy tedious plain-ſong grates my tender ears.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: 'Tis plain indeed, for Truth no deſcant needs,
Ʋna's her name, ſhe cannot be divided.

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.l: O but the ground it ſelf is nought, from whence
Thou canſt not reliſh out a good diviſion:
Therefore at length ſurceaſe, prove not ſtark mad,
Hopeleſſe to proſecute a hapleſſe ſute:
For though (perchance) thy firſt ſtrains pleaſing are,
I dare ingage mine ears, the cloze will jarre.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: If then your confidence eſteem my cauſe,
To be ſo frivolous and weakly wrought:
Why do you daily ſubtile plots deviſe,
To ſtop me from the ears of common Senſe,
Whom ſince our great Queen Pſyche hath ordain'd,
For his ſound wiſdome, our Vice-governour,
To him, and to his two ſo wiſe aſſiſtants,
Nimble Phantaſtes, and firm Memorie:
My ſelf and cauſe, I humbly do commit,
Let them but hear and judg, I wiſh no more,

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.l: Should they but know thy raſh preſumption,
They would correct it in the ſharpeſt ſort:
Good Jove what Senſe haſt thou to be a Senſe;
Since from the firſt foundation of the world,
We never were accounted more then five;
Yet you forſooth, an idle prating Dame,
Would fain increaſe the number, and up-ſtart
To our high ſeats, decking your babling ſelf
With uſurpt Titles of our dignity.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: An idle prating dame: know fond Auditus,
Records affirm my title full as good,
As his amongſt the five is counted beſt.

sp.speaker: AUD
sp.l: Lingua confeſs the truth, th'art wont to lie,

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: I ſay ſo too, therefore I do not lye,
But now ſpite of you all I ſpeak the truth.
You five among us ſubjects tyrannize,
Making the ſacred name of common Senſe,
A cloak to cover your enormities:
Hee bears the rule, hee's judg, but judgeth ſtill,
As hee's informed by your falſe evidence:
So that a plaintiff cannot have acceſs,
But through your gates he hears but what, nought els
But that thy crafty ears to him conveys,
And all he ſees is by proud Viſus ſhewed him:
And what he touches is by Tactus hand,
And ſmels I know but through Olfactus noſe,
Guſtus begins to him what ere he taſtes:
By theſe quaint tricks free paſſage hath been barr'd
That I could never equally be heard.
But well, 'tis well.

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.l: Lingua thy feeble ſex,
Hath hitherto with-held my ready hands
That long'd to pluck that nimble inſtrument.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: O horrible ingratitude? that thou
That thou of all the reſt ſhould'ſt threaten me:
Who by my means conceiv'ſt as many tongues,
As Neptune cloſeth Lands betwixt his armes:
The ancient Hebrew clad with myſteres,
The learned Greek rich in fit Epithetes,
Bleſt in the lovely marriage of pure words,
The Chaldee Wiſe, the Arabian Phyſicall,
The Romane Eloquent, the Tuſcane Grave,
The Braving Spaniſh, and the ſmooth tong'd French,
Theſe pretious Iewels that adorn thine ears,
All from my mouthes rich Cabbinet are ſtolne,
How oft haſt thou been chain'd unto my tongue,
Hang'd at my lips and raviſht with my words,
So that a ſpeech fair fether'd could not flie:
But thy ears pit-fall caught it inſtantly,
But now O Heavens!

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.l: O Heavens, thou wrong'ſt me much,
Thou wrong'ſt me much thus falſly to upbraid me:
Had not I granted thee the uſe of hearing,
That ſharp edg'd tongue whetted againſt her maſter,
Thoſe puffing lungs, thoſe teeth, thoſe dropſie lips,
That ſcalding throat, thoſe noſthrils full of ire:
Thy palate proper inſtruments of ſpeech,
Like to the winged chanters of the wood,
Uttring nought elſe but idle ſtiflements,
Tunes without ſenſe, words inarticulate:
Had ne're been able t'have abus'd me thus.
Words are thy Children, but of my begetting.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: Perfidious Liar, how can I endure thee?
Cal'ſt my unſpotted chaſtity in Queſtion:
O could I uſe the Breath mine anger ſpends,
I'de make thee know.

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.l: Heaven look on my diſtreſſe,
Defend me from this railing vipereſſe:
For if I ſtay her words, ſharp vinegar
Will fret me through, Lingua I muſt be gone:
I hear one call me more then earneſtly. Exit Auditus.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: Nay the loud cannoning of thunder-bolts,
Screeking of Wolves, houling of tortur'd Ghoſts,
Purſue thee ſtill, and fill thy amazed ears
With cold aſtoniſhment and horrid fears:
O how theſe ſenſes muffle common ſenſe:
And more, and more with pleaſing objects ſtrive,
To dull his judgement, and pervert his will
To their be-heſts, who were he not ſo wrapt
I' the dusky clouds of their dark policies,
Would never ſuffer right to ſuffer wrong:
Fie Lingua wilt thou now degenerate?
Art not a woman, doſt not love revenge?
Delightfull ſpeeches, ſweet perſwaſions
I have this long time us'd to get my right,
My right that is to make the Senſes ſix;
And have both name and power with the reſt.
Oft have I ſeaſoned ſavory periods,
With ſugred words, to delude Guſtus taſte,
And oft embeliſht my entreative phraſe
With ſmelling flowers of vernant Rhetorique,
Limming and flaſhing it with various Dyes,
To draw proud Viſus to me by the eyes:
And oft perfum'd my petitory ſtyle,
With Civet-ſpeech, t' entrap Olfactus Noſe,
And clad my ſelf in Silken Eloquence,
To allure the nicer touch of Tactus hand,
But all's become loſt labour, and my cauſe
Is ſtill procraſtinated; therefore now,
Hence ye baſe off-ſpring of a broken minde,
Supple intreaties and ſmooth flatteries:
Go kiſſe the love-ſick lips of puling Guls,
That ſtill their Brain to quench their loves diſdain;
Go guild the tongues of Bawds and Paraſites,
Come not within my thoughts; But thou Deceipt,
Break up the pleaſure of my Brim-full breſt,
Enrich my minde with ſubtile policies.
Well then Ile go, whither? nay, what know I?
And do, in faith I will, the devil knows what,
What if I ſet them all at variance,
And ſo obtein to ſpeak, it muſt be ſo.
It muſt be ſo, but how? there lyes the point:
How? thus t tut this device will never prove,
Augment it ſo, 'twill be too ſoon deſcri'd,
Or ſo, nor ſo 'tis too too dangerous.
Piſh, none of theſe, what if I take this courſe? ha?
Why there it goes, good, good, moſt excellent.
He that will catch Eels muſt diſturb the floud,
The Chicken's hatcht i'faith; for they are proud,
And ſoon will take a cauſe of diſagreement.

div.head: ACTUS 1. SCENA. 2.
div.stage: MENDACIO, attired in a Taffata ſuit of a light colour changeable, like an ordinary Page, Gloves, Hamper.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: I ſee the heavens nurſe my new-born device,
For loe my Page Mendacio comes already,
To file and burniſh that I hammer'd out,
Never in better time Mendacio,
What? haſt thou done?

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Done, yes long agoe.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Is't poſſible? thou ſhould'ſt diſpatch ſo ſoon?

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.l: Madame, I had no ſooner told
Tactus, that Guſtus would fain ſpeak with him:
But I ſpied Viſus, Guſtus and the reſt,
And ſerved them all with ſauce of ſeverall lyes,
Now the laſt Senſe I ſpake with was Olfactus,
Who having ſmelt the meaning of my meſſage,
Straight blew his noſe, and quickly puſt me hither;
But in the whirl-winde of his furious blaſt,
Had not by chance a Cobweb held me faſt,
Mendacio had been with you long ere this.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: Witneſs this lye, Mendacio's with me now,
But ſirra out of jeſting will they come?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: Yes and it like your Ladyſhip preſently;
Here may you have me preſt to flatter them.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: I'le flatter no ſuch proud Companions.
'Twill do no good, therefore I am determined
To leave ſuch baſeneſs.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Then ſhall I turn and bid them ſtay at home.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: No, for their coming hither to this grove,
Shall be a means to further my device;
Therefore I pray thee Mendacio go preſently,
Run you vile Ape.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: What? doſt thou ſtand?

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Till I know what to doe.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: S. pretious 'tis true,
So might thou finely out-run thine errand.
Haſt to my Cheſt.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: I, I.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: There ſhalt thou find,
A gorgeous Robe, and golden Coronet,
Convey them hither nimbly, let none ſee them.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Madam, I fly, I fly.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: But here you ſirra?
Lock up your fellow Servant, Veritas.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: I warrant you,
You need not fear, ſo long as I am with you.
sp.stage: He goes out, and comes in preſently.
sp.l: What colour is the Robe?

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: There is but one.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: The Key Madam, the Key.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: By Juno how forgetfull is ſudden ſpeed.
Here take it, Runne.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Ile be here inſtantly.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: Whilome this Crown and gorgious ornament,
Were the great prize, for which five Orators,
With the ſharp weapons of their tongues contended:
But all their ſpeeches were ſo equal wrought,
And a-like gracious, that if his were witty
His was as wiſe; the thirds fair eloquence
Did paralell the fourths firm gravity,
The laſts good geſture kept the Balance even
With all the reſt, ſo that the ſharpeſt eye,
And moſt judicious cenſor could not judge
To whom the hanging victory ſhould fall,
Therefore with one conſent they all agreed,
To offer up both Crown and Robe to me,
As the chief patroneſſe of their profeſſion,
Which heretofore I holily have kept,
Like to a miſers gold, to look on onely.
But now Ile put them to a better uſe,
And venture both in hope to—

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: Have not I hied me Madam? look you here,
What ſhall be done with theſe temptations?

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: They ſay a golden Ball,
Bred enmity betwixt three Goddeſſes,
So ſhall this Crown be author of debate,
Betwixt five Senſes.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Where ſhall it be laid?

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: There, there, there, 'tis well, ſo, ſo, ſo.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: A Crown's a pleaſing bait to look upon,
The craftieſt Fox will hardly ſcape this trap.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Come let us away, & leave it to the chance.

sp.speaker: MEND
sp.l: Nay rather let me ſtand cloſe here-abouts,
And ſee the event.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: Do ſo, and if they doubt
How it came there, fain them ſome pritty fable,
How that ſome God—

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: Tut, tut, tut, let me alone,
I that have fained ſo many hundred Gods,
Can eaſily forge ſome fable for the turn:
Whiſt Madame, away, away, you fright the Fowl,
Tactus comes hard by, look you,

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Is't he for certain?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes, 'tis he.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: 'Tis he indeed

div.head: ACT. 1. SCEN. 5.
div.stage: TACTUS, in a dark coloured Sattin mantle over a pair of ſilk Baſis, a Garland of Bayes mixt with white and red Roſes, upon a black Grogram, a Faulchion, wrought ſleeves, Buskins, &c.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Now chaſt Diana grant my Nets to hold!

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: The blaſting Childhood of the cheerful morn
Is almoſt grown a youth and over-climbes
Yonder gilt Eaſtern hills, about which time,
Guſtus moſt earneſtly importuned me,
To meet him here abouts, what cauſe I know not.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: You ſhall do ſhortly to your coſt I hope.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Sure by the Sunne it ſhould be Nine a clock.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: What a Star-gazer, will you nere look down?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: Cleer is the Sunne and blew the Firmament,
Me thinks the Heavens do ſmile.

sp.speaker: —MEN.
sp.l: At thy miſhap.
To look ſo high and ſtumble in a trap.

div.stage: Tactus ſtumbleth at the Robe and Crown.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.p: High thoughts have ſlippry feet, I had well nie faln.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Well doth he fall that riſeth with a fall.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: What's this!

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: O are you taken, 'tis in vain to ſtrive.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: How now!

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: You'l be ſo entangled ſtraight.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: A Crown!

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: That it will be heard.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: And a Robe!

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: To loſe your ſelf.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: A Crown and a Robe.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: It had been fitter for you, to have found a Fools Coate and a Bable, hey, hey.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.p: Jupiter, Jupiter how came this here?

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: O Sir Jupiter is making Thunder, he hears you not, here's one knowes better.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.l: 'Tis wondrous rich, ha, but ſure it is not ſo, ho,
Do I not ſleep and dream of this good luck, ha?
No I am awake and feel it now
Whoſe ſhould it be?

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Set up a Si quis for it.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.p: Mercury, All's mine own, here's none to cry half's mine.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: When I am gone.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: Tactus thy ſneezing ſomewhat did portend▪
Was ever man ſo fortunate as I?
To break his ſhinnes at ſuch a ſtumbling Block.
Roſes and Baies pack hence: this Crown and Robe,
My Brows and Body circles and inveſts.
How gallantly it fits me, ſure the ſlave,
Meaſur'd my head that wrought this Coronet.
They lie that ſay Complexions cannot change:
My Blood's ennobled, and I am transform'd,
Unto the ſacred temper of a King:
Methink I here my noble Paraſites
Styling me Caeſar, or great Alexander,
Licking my feet, and wondring where I got
This pretious oyntment: how my pace is mended,
How Princely do I ſpeak, how ſharp I threaten:
Peaſants Ile curb your head-ſtrong impudence:
And make you tremble when the Lion roars,
Yea earth-bred worms, O for a looking glaſſe:
Poets will write whole Volumes of this Change:
Where's my attendants? Come hither Sirra quickly,
Or by the wings of Hermes.—

div.head: ACT. 1. SCEN. 7.
div.stage: OLFACTUS, in a Garland of Bayes intermingled with white and red Roſes upon a falſe hair, his ſleeves wrought with flowers under a Damaskt mantle over a pair of ſilk Baſes, a pair of Buskins drawn with riband, a flower in his hand.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: Ay me Olfactus comes, I cal'd too ſoon,
Hee'l have half part I fear; what ſhall I do?
Where ſhall I run? how ſhall I ſhift him off?
sp.stage: Tactus wraps up the Robe and Crown, and ſits upon them.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.l: This is the time and this the place appointed,
Where Viſus promis'd to conferre with me.
I think he's there — No, no, 'tis Tactus ſure.
How now? What makes you ſit ſo nicely?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: It's paſt imagination, it's ſo indeed.

sp.speaker: OLF
sp.p: How faſt his deeds are fixed, and how melancholly he looks. Tactus, Tactus.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: For this is true Mans life is wondrous brittle.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: He's mad I think, he talks ſo idlely, ſo ho, Tactus.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: And many have been metamorphoſed,
To ſtranger matters and more uncouth forms.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: I muſt go nearer him, he doth not hear.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: And yet methinks, I ſpeak as I was wont
And—

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Olfactus as thou loveſt come not near me,

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: Why? art thou hatching eggs th'art feard to break them?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Touch me not leſt thou chance to break my life.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: What's this under thee?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: If thou meddle with me I am utterly undone.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: Why man, what ayls thee?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: Let me alone and Ile tell thee,
Lately I came from fine Fantaſtes houſe.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: So I beleeve for th'art very fooliſh.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: No ſooner had I parted out of doors,
But up I held my hands before my face:
To ſhield mine eyes from th'lights piercing beams,
When I proteſt I ſaw the Sun as clear,
Through theſe my palms, as through a proſpective:
No marvel, for when I beheld my fingers,
I ſaw my fingers near transform'd to glaſſe,
Opening my Breaſt, my Breaſt was like a window,
Through which I plainly did perceive my heart:
In whoſe two Concaves I diſcern'd my thoughts,
Confus'ly lodged in great multitudes.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha, why this is excellent,
Momus himſelf can find no fault with thee,
Thou'ſt make a paſſing live Anatomy.
And decide the Queſtion much diſputed,
Betwixt the Galeniſts and Ariſtotle.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: But when I had ariv'd and ſet me down,
Viewing my ſelf, my ſelf ay me was changed.
As thou now ſeeſt to a perfect Urinal.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: T'a perfect Urinal, O monſtrous, monſtrous, art not mad to think ſo?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: I do not think ſo, but I ſay I am ſo;
Therefore Olfactus come not near I adviſe you.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.l: See the ſtrange working of dull melancholly;
Whoſe droſſie drying the feeble Brain,
Corrupts the ſenſe, deludes the Intellect.
And in the ſouls fair table falſly graves,
Whole ſquadrons of phantaſtical Chimera's,
And thouſand vain imaginations:
Making ſome think their heads as big as horſes,
Some that th'ar dead, ſome that th'ar turnd to Wolves:
As now it makes him think himſelf all glaſſe,
Tactus diſſwade thy ſelf, thou doſt but think ſo.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: Olfactus if thou loveſt me get thee gone,
I am an Urinal I dare not ſtirre,
For fear of cracking in the Bottome.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: Wilt thou ſit thus all day?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Unleſſe thou help me.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: Bedlam muſt help thee, what wouldſt have me do?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: Go to the City make a Caſe fit for me:
Stuff it with wool, then come again and fetch.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, thou'lt be laught out of caſe and countenance.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: I care not, ſo it muſt be, or I cannot ſtirre.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p:
I had beſt leave troubling him, he's obſtinate, (Urinal I leave you) but above all things take heed Jupiter ſees you not, for if he do, he'l nere make
water in ſive again; thou'lt ſerve his turn ſo fit to carry his water unto Aeſculapius, Farewell Urinal, Farewell.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Speak not ſo lowd, the ſound's enough to crack me, What is he gone? I an Urinal, ha, ha, ha, I proteſt I might have had my face waſht finely, if he had meant to abuſe me: I an Urinal, ha, ha, ha, go to, Urinal you have ſcapt a fair ſcouring, well Ile away, and get me to mine own houſe, there Ile lock up my ſelf faſt, playing the Chimick, augmenting this one Crown to troops of Angels, with which gold-winged meſſengers, I mean,
sp.l: To work great wonders, as to build and purchaſe,
Fare daintily, tie up mens tongues, and looſe them,
Command their lives, their goods, their liberties,
And captive all the world with chains of gold:
Hey, hey, tery linkum tinkum.
sp.stage: He offers to go out, but comes in ſuddenly amazed.
sp.l: O Hercules!
Fortune the Queen delights to play with me,
Stopping my paſſage with the ſight of Viſus;
But as he makes hither, Ile make hence,
There's more waies to the wood than one.
sp.stage: He offers to go out at the other door, but returns again in haſt.
sp.l: What more Devils to affright me?
O Diabolo, Guſtus comes here to vex me:
So that I poor wretch, am like a Shittle-cock betwixt two Battledoors, If I run there, Viſus beats me to Scilla, If here, then Guſtus blows me to Carybdis.
Neptune hath ſworn my hope ſhall ſuffer ſhipwrack..
What ſhall I ſay?
Mine Urinal's too thin to bide the fury of ſuch ſtorms as theſe.

stage.p: VISUS, in a Garland of Bays, mixt with white and red Roſes, a light coloured Taffata mantle ſtriped with ſilver, and fring'd upon green ſilk Baſes, Buskins, &c.
GUSTUS, in the ſame faſhion, differing only in colour.
TACTUS, in a corner of the Stage.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Guſtus good day.

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.l: I cannot have a bad,
Meeting ſo fair an omen as your ſelf.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Shall I? wilt prove? ha? well 'tis beſt to venture.

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: Saw you not Tactus, I ſhould ſpeak with him.

sp.speaker: TACT
sp.p: Perchance ſo, a ſudden lie hath beſt luck.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.l: That face is his, or elſe mine eye's deceiv'd,
Why how now Tactus, what ſo gorgious?

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: Where didſt thou get theſe fair habiliments?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: Stand back I charge you as you love your lives,
By Stix, the firſt that toucheth me ſhall die.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: I can diſcern no weapons, will he kill us?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Kill you? not I, but come not neer me you had beſt.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Why, art thou mad?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: Friends as you love your lives,
Venture not once to come within my reach.

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: Why doſt threaten ſo?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: I do not threaten, but in pure love adviſe you for the beſt,
Dare not to touch me, but hence fly apace,
Adde wings unto your feet and ſave your lives.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Why what's the matter Tactus prethe tell me?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: If you will needs jeopard your lives ſo long,
As hear the ground of my amazedneſſe,
Then for your better ſafety ſtand aſide.

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.l: How full of ceremonies, ſure he'l conjure,
For ſuch like Robes Magicians uſe to wear.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.l: Ile ſee the end, though he ſhould unlock Hell:
And ſet th'infernall haggs at liberty.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: How raſh is man on hidden arms to ruſh!
It was my chance, O chance moſt miſerable!
To walk that way that to Crumena leads.

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: You mean Cremona a little Town hard by.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: I ſay Crumena, called Vacua,
A Town which doth, and alwaies hath belong'd,
Chiefly to Scholars: from Crumena wals,
I ſaw a man came ſtealing craftily,
Apparelled in this veſture which I wear,
But ſeeing me eſt-ſoons, he took his heels,
And threw his garment from him all in haſt,
Which I perceiving to be richly wrought,
Took it me up: But good now get you gone,
Warn'd by my harms, and ſcape my miſery.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: I know no danger, leave theſe circumſtances.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.l: No ſooner had I put it on my back,
But ſuddenly mine eyes began to dim,
My joynts wax ſore, and all my body burn
With moſt inteſtine torture, and at length,
It was too evident, I had caught the plague.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.l: The plague, away good Guſtus lets be gone,
I doubt 'tis true, now I remember me,
Crumena Vacua never wants the plague.

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: Tactus Ile put my ſelf in jeopardy to pleaſure thee.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: No gentle Guſtus, your abſence is the only thing I wiſh,
Leſt I infect you with my company.

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: Farewell. Exit Guſtus.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: I willingly would ſtay to do thee good.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: A thouſand thanks, but ſince I needs muſt die,
Let it ſuffice, death only murthers me,
Oh 'twould augment the dolour of my death,
To know my ſelf the moſt unhappy Bow,
Through wch pale death ſhould aim his ſhafts at you.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.l: Tactus farewell, yet die with this good hope,
Thy corps ſhall be interred as they ought. Exit Viſus.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.l: Go make my Tomb, provide my funerals, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha,
Excellent Aſſes thus to be deluded,
Bewail his death and cruel deſtinies,
That lives, and laughs your fooleries to ſcorn,
But where's my Crown, oh here: I well deſerve,
Thus to be crowned for two great victories, ha, ha, ha,
Viſus take care my corps be well interr'd:
Go make my Tomb, and write upon the Stone;

l.hi: Here lies the Senſe, that lying gul'd them all,
With a falſe plague, and fained Ʋrinal.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: O Jupiter, 'tis Auditus, all's mard, I doubt the ſlie knave hears ſo far, but yet Ile grope him: how now Ears, what make you here, ha?

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: Nay, what make you here, I pray what were you talking even now, of an Aſſe, and a Crown, and an Urinal, and a plague?

sp.speaker: TA.
sp.p: A plague on you, what I?

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: Oh, what you.

sp.speaker: TA
sp.p: O I had well nigh forgot nothing, but I ſay—

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.p: That if a man (do you mark ſir) being ſick of the plague (do you ſee ſir) had a, a, a, hem, hem, (this cold troubles me, It makes me cough ſometimes extreamly,) had a French Crown, (ſir you underſtand me) lying by him, and (come hither, come hither) and would not beſtow two pence (do you hear) to buy an Urinal (do you mark me) to carry his water to the Phyſician, (hem)

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: What of all this?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p:
I ſay ſuch a one was a very Aſſe, this was all I uſe to ſpeak to my ſelf, when I am alone; but Auditus, when ſhall we hear a new ſet of ſinging
books, or th'viols, or the conſort of Inſtruments.

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: This was not all, for I heard mention of a Tomb, and an Epitaph.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: True, true, I made my ſelf merry with this Epitaph, upon ſuch a fools Tomb thus a, thus, thus, plague brought this man, (foh I have forgotten) O thus, plague brought this man (ſo, ſo, ſo) unto his burial, becauſe, becauſe, becauſe, (hem, hem) becauſe he would not buy an Urinal, come, come Auditus, ſhall we hear thee play, the Lyroway, or the Lute-way ſhall we, or the Cornet, or any Muſick, I am greatly revived when I hear.

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: Tactus, Tactus, this will not ſerve, I heard all, you have not found a Crown: you, no, you have not.

div.head: ACT. 1. SCEN. Ʋltima.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Peace, peace, faith peace, come hither, hark thee good now.

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: I cannot hold I muſt needs tell.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: O do not, do not, do not, come hither, will you be a fool?

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Had he not wings upon his feet and ſhoulders?

sp.speaker: MEN
sp.l: Yes, yes, and a fine wand in his hand,
Coriouſly wrapped with a pair of ſnakes.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Will half content you, piſh 'twill nere be known.

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: My life, 'twas Mercury.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: I do not know his name, but this I am ſure his hat had wings upon't.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Doubtles 'twas he, but ſay my Boy what did he?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: Firſt I beheld him hovering in the air,
And then down ſtooping with a hundred gires:
His feet he fixed on Mount Chephalon,
From whence he flew and lighted on that plain,
And with diſdainfull ſteps ſoon glided thither:
Whither arived, he ſuddenly unfolds
A gorgeous Robe, and glittering ornament,
And lays them all, upon that hillock:
This done he wafts his wand, took wing again,
And in a moment vaniſht out of ſight,
With that mine eies 'gan ſtare, and heart grew cold,
And all my quivering joynts with ſweat bedew'd:
My heels my thought had wings as well as his,
And ſo away I runne; but by the way,
I met a man as I thought coming thither,

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: What marks had he?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: He had a great—what this is he, this is he:

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: What Tactus?

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: This was the plague vext him ſo, Tactus your Grave gapes for you, are you ready?

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.l: Since you muſt needs die, do as others do,
Leave all your goods behinde you; bequeath the
Crown and Robe to your Executors.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: No ſuch matter, I like the Egyptian Knights,
• or the more ſtate, will be buried in them.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Come, come, deliver:

div.stage: Viſus ſnatcheth the Crown and ſees letters graven in it.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: What will you take my purſe from me?

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.l: No but a Crown, that's juſt more then your own.
Ha, what's this? 'tis a very ſmal hand,
What Inſcription is this?

l.hi: He of the five that proves himſelf the beſt,
Shall have his Temples with this Coronet bleſt.

sp.l: This Crown is mine, and mine this garment is,
For I have alwaies been accounted beſt.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Next after me, I as your ſelf at any time: beſides I found it firſt, therefore 'tis mine.

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: Neither of yours but mine as much as both.

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: And mine the moſt of any of you all.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Give me it or elſe —

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Ile make you late repent it ———

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: Preſumptuous as you are———

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: Spite of your teeth——

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: Never till now▪ a ha, it works apace,
Viſus I know tis yours, and yet methinks,
Auditus you ſhould have ſome challenge to it,
But that your title Tactus is ſo good:
Guſtus I would ſwear the Coronet were yours,
What will you all go braule about a trifle:
View but the pleaſant coaſt of Microcoſm,
Iſt not great pity to be rent with warres,
Iſt not a ſhame, to ſtain with briniſh tears,
The ſmiling cheeks of ever-cheerfull peace,
Iſt not farre better to live quietly,
Than broyl in fury of diſſention;
Give me the Crown, ye ſhall not diſagree,
If I can pleaſe you; Ile play Paris part,
And moſt unpartial judge the controverſie:

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Sauce-box go meddle with your Ladies fanne, and prate not here.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: I ſpeak not for my ſelf, but for my Countries ſafe commodity.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Sirra be ſtill.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: Nay and you be ſo hot, the devil part you,
Ile to Olfactus and ſend him amongſt you.
O that I were Alecto for your ſakes:
How liberally would I beſtow my ſnakes.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.l: Tactus upon thine honour,
I challenge thee to meet me here,
Strong as thou canſt provide in th'afternoon.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.l: I undertake the Challenge, and here's my hand,
In ſign thou ſhalt be anſwered.

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.l: Tactus Ile joyn with thee, on this condition,
That if we win, he that fought beſt of us,
Shall have the Crown, the other wear the Robe.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Give me your hand, I like the motion.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.l: Auditus ſhall we make our forces double,
Upon the ſame terms.

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: Very willingly:

sp.speaker: VIS
sp.l: Come lets away, fear not the victory.
Right's more advantage, than an hoſt of ſouldiers.

div.head: Actus 2. Scena 1.
div.stage: APPETITUS, A long lean Raw-bon'd fellow in a Souldiers coat, a ſword, &c.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: I long to ſee thoſe hot-ſpur ſenſes at it, they ſay they have gallant preparations, and not unlikely, for moſt of the ſouldiers are ready in Arms ſince the laſt field fought againſt their yearly enemy Meleager, and his wife Acraſia; that Conqueſt hath ſo fleſht them, that no peace can hold them. But had not Meleager been ſick, and Acraſia drunk, the ſenſes might have whiſtled for the victory.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Foh, what a ſtink of gunpowder is yonder?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Who's this! oh, oh, 'tis Appetitus, Guſtus his hungry Paraſite.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: I cannot indure the ſmoking of Gunnes, the thundring of drums, I had rather hear the merry hacking of pot-herbs, and ſee the reaking of a hot Capon. If they would uſe no other Bucklers in warre, but ſhields of Brawn, brandiſh no ſwords but ſweards of Bacon, trail no ſpears, but ſparribs of Pork, and inſtead of Harquebuſs pieces diſcharge Hartichockpies, toſſe no pikes but boyled Pickrels, then Appetitus would rouſe up his creſt, and bear up himſelf with the proudeſt.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Ah here's a youth ſtark naught at a trench but old dog at a trencher, a tall ſquire at a ſquare table

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: But now my good maſters muſt pardon me I am not for their ſervice, for their ſervice is without ſervice, and indeed their ſervice is too hoat for my diet. But what, If I be not my ſelf, but only this be my ſpirit that wanders up and down, and Appetitus be kil • in the Camp, the Devil he is as ſoon, how's tha • poſſible? tut, tut, I know I am, I, I am Appetitus, and alive too, by this Infallible token, that I feel my ſel • hungry.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Thou might'ſt have taken a better token o • thy ſelf, by knowing thou art a fool.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Well then, though I made my fellow ſouldier • admire the beauty of my back, and wonder at the nimbleneſſe of my heels, yet now will I at ſafety a • home, tell in what dangers they are abroad, Ile ſpea • nothing but guns, and glaves, and ſtaves, and phalanges, and ſquadrons, and barracadoes, ambuſcadoes, palmedoes blank point dept, counterpoint, counterſcraf, ſallies, and lies, ſaladoes, tarantantaras, ranta, tara, tara, hey.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: I muſt take the fife out of his mouth, or he'l nere adone▪

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: But above all Ile be ſure on my knees to thank the great—

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Who am I, who am I, who I?

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: By the bloud-ſtain'd fauchion of Mauors —I am on your ſide

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Why, who am I?

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Are you a ſouldier?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Then you are maſter Helluo the Bear-ward,

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: No, no, he's dead.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Or Gulono the gutty Serjeant, or Delphino the Vintner, or elſe I know you not, for theſe are all my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Would I were hang'd, if I be any of theſe,

sp.speaker: APP
sp.p: What Mendacio, by the faith of a Knight thou art welcome, I muſt borrow thy Whetſtone to ſharpen the edges of my martial complements.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: By the faith of a Knight, what a pox, where are thy Spurres?

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: I need no ſpurres, I ride like Pegaſus on a winged horſe, on a ſwift Gennet, my Boy, called fear.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: What ſhould'ſt thou fear in the wars? he's not a good ſouldier that hath not a good ſtomack.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: O, but the ſtink of powder ſpoils Appetitus ſtomack, and then thou know'ſt when 'tis gone, Appetitus is dead, therefore I very manfully drew my ſword, and flouriſht it bravely about mine ears, kiſt, and finding my ſelf hurt, moſt manfully run away.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: All heart indeed, for thou ran'ſt like a Hart out of the field:
It ſeems then the Senſes mean to fight it out.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: I, and out-fight themſelves I think, and all about a trifle, a paltry bable, found I know not where.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p:
Thou art deceived, they fight for more then
that, a thing called Superiority, of which the Crow • is but an Embleme.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Mendacio hang this Superiority, Crown me no Crown but Bacchus Crown of Roſes, give me no Scepter, but a far (apons legge, to ſhew tha • I am the great King of Hungary, therefore I prethe • talk no more of State-matters, but in brief, tell me my little raſcall, how thou haſt ſpent thy time this many a day?

sp.speaker: MEN
sp.p: Faith in ſome credit ſince thou ſaw'ſt me laſt▪

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: How ſo, where?

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Every where; in the Court your Gentlewomen hang me at their Apron ſtrings, and that makes them anſwer ſo readily. In the City I am honour'd like a God, none ſo well acquainted with your Tradeſmen: your Lawyers all the Term time hire me of my Lady, your Gallants if they hear my name abuſed, they ſtab for my ſake: your Travellers ſo dote upon me as paſſes, O they have good reaſon, for I have carried them to many a good meal, under the Countenance of my familiarity: Nay your States-men have oftentimes cloſely conveyed me under their tongues, to make their policies more currant: As for old men they challenge my Company by authority.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: I am exceeding glad of your great promotion.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Now when I am diſpoſed, I can Philophy it in the Univerſity, with the ſubtileſt of them all.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: I cannot be perſwaded that th'art acquainted with Scholars ever ſince thou wert preſt to death in a Print-houſe.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: No, why I was the firſt founder of the three ſects of Phyloſophy, except one of the Peripateticks who acknowledge Ariſtotle (I confeſs) their great Grand-father.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Thou Boy, how is this poſſible? thou art but a Child and there were ſects of Philoſophy before thou wert born.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Appetitus, thou miſtakeſt me, I tell thee, 3000 years ago was Mendacio born in Greece, nurſt in Creete, and ever ſince honoured every where: Ile be ſworn I held old Homers pen when he writ his Iliads and his Odyſſes.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Thou hadſt need, for I hear ſay he was blind.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: I helped Herodotus to pen ſome part of his Muſes, lent Pliny ink to write his Hiſtory, rounded Rabalais in the ear when he hiſtorified Pantagruell; as for Lucian, I was his Genius, O thoſe two Books De Vera Hiſtoria, howſoever they go under his Name, Ile be ſworn I write them every tittle.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Sure as I am Hungry, thou'ſt have it for lying. But haſt thou ruſted this later time for want of exerciſe?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p:
Nothing leſſe, I muſt confeſſe I would fain have jogged Stow and great Hollinſhead on
their elbows, when they were about their Chronicles, and as I remember Sir John Mandevils Travels, and a great part of the Decads were of my doing. But for the mirror of Knight-hood, Bevis of Southampton, Palmerin of England, Amadis of Gaule, Huon de Burdeaux, Sir Guy of Warwick, Martin mar-prelate, Robin-hood, Garragantua, Gevilion, and a thouſand ſuch exquiſite monuments as theſe, no doubt but they breathe on my breath up and down.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Downwards Ile ſwear, for there's ſtinking lies in them.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: But what ſhould I light a Candle to the bright Sunne ſhine of my glorious renown, the whole world is full of Mendacios fame.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: And ſo it will be ſo long as the world is full of fame.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: But Sirra, how haſt thou done this long time?

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: In as much requeſt as thy ſelf. To begin with the Court, as thou didſt, I lie with the Ladies all night, and that's the reaſon they call for Cullies, and Gruellies ſo early before their prayers, your Gallants never ſup, break-faſt or beaver without me.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: That's falſe, for I have ſeen them eat with a full ſtomack.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p:
True, but becauſe they know a little thing drives me from them, therefore in midſt of meat they preſent me with ſome ſharp ſauce or a diſh of
delicate Anchoves, or a Caviare, to entice me back again; nay more, your old Sirs that hardly go without a prop, will walk a mile or two every day to renew their acquaintance with me, as for the Academy, it is beholding to me for adding the eighth province unto noble Heptarchy of the liberall ſciences.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: What's that I prethee.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.l: The moſt deſired and honourable art of Cookery.
Now Sirra in the City I am—ſt, ſt.
O the body of a Louſe.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: What art a louſe in the City?

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Not a word more, for yonder comes Phantaſtes, and ſome body elſe.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: What a pox can Phantaſtes do?

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Work a miracle if he would prove wiſe.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: 'Tis he indeed, the vileſt nup: yet the fool loves me exceedingly, but I care not for his company, for if he once catch me, I ſhall never be rid of him.

stage.p:
PHANTASTES, A ſwart complexion'd fellow, but quick ey'd, in a white Sattin doublet of one faſhion, green velvet hoſe of another: A phantaſticall has with a plume of fethers of ſeveral colours, a little ſhort taffaty cloak, a pair of Buskins cut, drawn
out with ſundry coloured Ribands, with ſcarfs hung about him, after all faſhions, and of all colours, rings, Jewels, a Fanne, and in every place other odd complements.
HEURESIS, A nimble ſprighted page in the neweſt faſhion, with a garland of Bayes, &c.

sp.speaker: PHAN.
sp.p: Sirra Boy Heureſis? boy how now biting your nails?

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: Three things have troubled my brain this many a day, and juſt now, when I was laying hold on the Invention of them, your ſudden call, made them like Tantalus apples, fly from my fingers.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Some great matters queſtionleſs, what were they?

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: The quadrature of a circle, the Philoſophers ſtone, and the next way to the Indies.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Thou doſt well to meditate on theſe three things at once, for they'l be found out altogether, ad gracas calendas, but let them paſſe, and carry the conceit I told you this morning, to the party you wot of. In my imagination 'tis Capritious, 'twill take I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: I will Sir: But what ſay you to the Gentleman that was with you yeſterday?

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: O I think thou meaneſt him that made nineteen ſonnets of his Miſtreſs Busk-point:

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: The ſame, the ſame, Sir: You promis'd to help him out with th' twentieth.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: By Jupiters cloven pate 'tis true; but we witty fellows are ſo forgetfull, but ſtay, hu, hu, carry him this:

lg.l: The gordian knot which Alexander great,

l.hi: Did whilom cut with his all conquering ſword:
Was nothing like thy Busk-point pretty Peate,
Nor could ſo fair an augury afford.

sp.p: Then to conclude let him pervert Catullus his zonam ſolvit diù ligatam, thus, thus,

l.hi: Which if I chance to cut or elſe unty,
Thy little world Ile conquer preſently.

sp.p: 'Tis pretty, pretty, tell him 'twas extemporal.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: Well Sir, but now for Maſter Inamorato's Love-letter.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Some netling ſtuffy faith; let him write thus: Moſt heart commanding fac't Gentlewoman, even as the ſtone in India called Baſiliſcus, hurts all that looks on it: and as the Serpent in Arabia called Smaragdus, delighteth the ſight, ſo does thy celeſtial orb aſſimilating eyes, both pleaſe, and in pleaſing wound my Love-darted heart.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: But what trick ſhall I invent for the concluſion?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Piſh, any thing: Love will miniſter Ink for the reſt:
He that once begun well, hath half done, let him begin again, and there's all.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: Maſter Gullio ſpoke for a new faſhion, What for him?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: A faſhion for his ſute—let him button it down the ſleeve with four elbows, and ſo make it the pure heiroglyphick of a fool.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: Nay then let me requeſt one thing of you.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: What's that Boy? by this fair hand thou ſhalt have it.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: Miſtreſſe Superbia a Gentlewoman of my acquaintance wiſht me to deviſe her a new ſet for her Ruff, and an odde tire, I pray Sir, help me out with it.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Ah Boy in my conceit it's a hard matter to perform, theſe women have well nigh tired me, with deviſing tires for them, and ſet me at a non plus for new ſets, their heads are ſo light, and their eyes ſo coy, that I know not how to pleaſe them.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: I pray Sir, ſhe hath a bad face, and fain would have Sutors, Phantaſtical and odd apparel, would perchance draw ſome body to look on her.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: If her face be nought, in my opinion, the more view it, the worſe, bid her wear the multitude of her deformities under a Mask, till my leaſure will ſerve to deviſe ſome durable, and unſtained bluſh of painting.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: Very good Sir.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Away then, hye thee again, meet me at the Court within this hour at the fartheſt.

Oh heavens, how have I been troubled theſe later
times with Women, Fools, Babes, Taylers, Poets, Swaggerers, Guls, Ballad-makers, they have almoſt diſrobed me of all the toys and trifles I can deviſe; were it not that I pity the poor multitude of Printers, theſe Sonnet-mongers ſhould ſtarve for conceits, for all Phantaſtes. But theſe puling Lovers, I cannot but laugh at them and their Encomions of their Miſtreſſes. They make forſooth her hair of Gold, her eyes of Diamond, her cheeks of Roſes, her lips of Rubies, her teeth of Pearl, and her whole body of Ivory: and when they have thus Idol'd her like Pigmalion, they fall down and worſhip her. Pſyche, thou haſt laid a hard task upon my ſhoulders, to invent at every ones ask, were it not that I refreſh my dulneſſe once a day with my moſt Angelical preſence, 'twere unpoſſible for me to undergo it.

div.head: ACTUS 2 SCENA 3.
div.stage: COMMUNIS SENSUS, A grave man in a Black velvet Caſſock like a Councellor, ſpeaks coming out of the door.

sp.speaker: COM. S.
sp.p: I cannot ſtay, I tell you 'tis more then time I were at Court, I know my Sovereign Pſyche hath expected me this hour.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p:
In good time, younder comes Commonſenſe,
I imagine it ſhould be he by his voice.

sp.speaker: COM. S.
sp.p: Crave my counſell, tell me what manner of man he is? Can he entertain a man into his houſe, can he hold his Velvet Cap in one hand, and vale his bonnet with the other? Knows he how to become a Scarlet gown, hath he a pair of freſh poſts at his door?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: He's about ſome haſty State-matters, he talks of poſts methinks.

sp.speaker: COM S.
sp.p: Can he part a couple of Dogs brawling in the ſtreet? why then chooſe him Mayor, upon my credit he'l prove a wiſe Officer.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Save you my Lord, I have attended your leiſure this hour.

sp.speaker: COM. S.
sp.p: Fie upon't, what a toil have I had to chooſe them a Mayor yonder? there's a fuſty Currier will have this man: there's a Chandler wipes his noſe on his ſleeve, and ſwears it ſhall not be ſo. There's a Muſtard-maker looks as keen as Viniger, will have another: O this many headed multitude, it's a hard matter to pleaſe them!

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Eſpecially where the multitude is ſo well headed. But I pray you where's Maſter Memory? hath he forgotten himſelf that he is not here?

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: 'Tis high time he were at Court, I would he would come.

stage.p: MEMORY, An old decrepit man, in a black Velvet Caſſock, a Taffaty Gown furred, with white Grogram, a white beard, Velvet ſlippers, a Watch, Staff, &c.

ANAMNESTES his Page, in a grave Sattin ſute Purple, Buskins, a Garland of Bayes and Roſemary, a gimmall ring, with one link hanging, Ribbands and Threds tied to ſome of his fingers, in his hand a pair of Table books, &c.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: How ſoon a wiſe man ſhall have his wiſh?

sp.speaker: COM. SE.
sp.p: Memory the ſeaſon of your coming is very ripe.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Had you ſtaid a little longer 'twould have been ſtark rotten.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: I am glad I ſav'd it from the Swine — Spretious I have forgot ſomething: O my purſe, my purſe, why Anamneſtes? Remembrance where art thou, Anamneſtes Remembrance, that vild Boy is alwaies gadding, I remember he was at my heels, even now, and now the vild Raſcal is vaniſht.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Is he not here? why then in my imagination he's left behind, O la Anamneſtes remembrance.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: (running in haſt) Anon, anon, ſir anon, anon ſir, anon, anon ſir, anon, anon ſir.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: Ha ſirra, what a brawling's here?

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: I do but give you an anſwer with anon Sir.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: You anſwer ſweetly, I have cal'd you three or four times one after another.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: Sir, I hope I anſwered you three or four times one in the neck of another. But if your good worſhip have lent me any more cals, tell me, and Ile repay them as I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: Leave your tattle, had you come at firſt I had not ſpent ſo much breath in vain.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: The truth is Sir, the firſt time you called, I heard you not, the ſecond I underſtood you not, the third I knew not whether it were you or no: the fourth I could not tell where you were, and that's the reaſon I anſwered ſo ſuddenly.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: Go ſirra, run, ſeek every where, I have loſt my purſe ſomewhere.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: I go Sir: Go ſirra, ſeek, run, I have loſt, bring, here's a Dogs life, with a pox, ſhall I be alwaies uſed like a water-Spaniel.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: Come good Maſter Regiſter, I wonder you be ſo late now adaies.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: My good Lord, I remember that I knew your Grandfather in this your place, and I remember your Grandfathers great Grandfathers, Grandfathers Fathers, Father, yet in thoſe daies I never remember that any of them could ſay, that Regiſter Memory ever broke one minute of his appointment.

sp.speaker: COM. S.
sp.p: Why good Father, why are you ſo late now adaies?

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: Thus 'tis, the moſt cuſtomers I remember my ſelf to have, are (as your Lordſhip knows) Scholars, and now adaies the moſt of them are become Criticks, bringing me home ſuch paltry things to lay up for them, that I can hardly find them again.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Jupiter, Jupiter, I had thought theſe Flies had bit none but my ſelf, Do Criticks tickle you yfaith?

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: Very familiarly: for they muſt know of me forſooth, how every idle word is written in all the muſty moth-eaten Manuſcripts, kept in all the old Libraries in every City betwixt England and Peru.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Indeed I have noted theſe times to affect Antiquities more than is requiſite.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: I remember in the age of Aſſaracus and Ninus, and about the warres of Thebes, and the ſiege of Troy, there was few things committed to my charge, but thoſe that were well worthy the preſerving, but now every trifle muſt be wrapped up in the volume of Eternity. A rich pudding-wife, or a Cobler cannot die but I muſt immortalize his Name with an Epitaph: A dog cannot piſſe in a Noblemans ſhoe, but it muſt be ſprinkled into the Chronicles, ſo that I never could remember my Treaſure more full, and never emptier of Honourable, and true Heroicall actions.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p:
By your leave Memory, you are not alone troubled, Chronologers many of them are ſo Phantaſtick, as when they bring a Captain to the Combat, lifting up his revengefull arm to diſ-part the head of
his enemy, they'l hold up his arms ſo long till they have beſtowed three or four pages in deſcribing the gold hilts of his threatning Fauchion: So that in my Fancy the Reader may well wonder his adverſary ſtabs him not before he ſtrikes; moreover they are become moſt palpable flatterers, alwaies begging at my gates for Invention.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: This is a great fault in a Chronologer to turn Paraſite: An abſolute Hiſtory ſhould be in fear of none, neither ſhould he write any thing more then truth for friendſhip, or leſs for hate, but keep himſelf equal and conſtant in all his diſcourſes, but for us, we muſt be contented, for as our Honours increaſe, ſo muſt the burthen of the cares of our Offices urge us to wax heavy.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: But not till our backs break, s'lud there was never any ſo haunted as I am, this day there comes a Sophiſter to my houſe, knocks at my door, his errand being ask'd forſooth his anſwer was, to borrow a fair ſute of conceits out of my wardrobe, to apparell, a ſhew he had in hand, and what think you is the plot?

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: Nay I know not, for I am little acquainted with ſuch toies.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Mean-while he's ſomewhat acquainted with you, for he's bold to bring your perſon upon the Stage.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: What me? I cannot remember, that I was ever brought upon the Stage before.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Yes you and you, and my ſelf, with all my Phantaſticall tricks and humors, but I trow I have fitted him with Fooleries, I truſt he'l never trouble me again.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: O times! O manners! when Boyes dare to traduce men in authority, was ever ſuch an attempt heard!

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: I remember there was For (to ſay the truth) at my laſt being at Athens (It is now, let me ſee, about 1800 years ago) I was at a Comedy of Ariſtophanes making, (I ſhall never forget it) The Arch-governour of Athens took me by the hand and placed me, and there I ſay, I ſaw Socrates abuſed moſt groſly, himſelf being then a preſent ſpectator: I remember he ſate full againſt me, and did not ſo much as ſhew the leaſt countenance of diſcontent.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: In thoſe daies it was lawfull, but now the abuſe of ſuch liberty is unſufferable.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Think what you will of it, I think 'tis done, and I think it is acting by this time; hark, hark, what drumming's yonder, Ile lay my life they are come to preſent the ſhew I ſpake of.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: It may be ſo; ſtay we'l ſee what 'tis.

div.head: ACT. 2. SCEN. 5.
div.stage: LINGUA. MENDACIO. COM. SEN. and the reſt.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Fain thy ſelf in great haſte.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: I warrant you Madam: I doubt 'tis in vain to run, by this they are all paſt overtaking.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Is not this Lingua that is in ſuch haſt?

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Yes, yes, ſtand ſtill.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: I muſt ſpeak with him.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Aſſure your ſelf they are all at Court ere this.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Run after them, for unleſſe he know it—

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: O iſt your Lordſhip: I beſeech you pardon me; haſt and fear, I proteſt put out mine eyes: I lookt ſo long for you, that I knew not when I had found you.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: In my conceit, that's like the man that enquired, who ſaw his Aſſe, when himſelf rid on him.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: O my heart beats ſo, fie, fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: I am ſo weary, fo, fo, fo, fo.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: I prethee Lingua make an end.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Let me begin firſt I beſeech you, but if you will needs have the end firſt, thus 'tis. The Commonwealth of Microſme at this inſtant ſuffers the pangs of death, 'tis gaſping for breath. Will you have all? 'tis poyſned.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: What Pothecary durſt be ſo bold as make ſuch a confection? ha what poyſon iſt?

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: A golden Crown.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: I miſtake, or elſe Galen in his Book De ſanitate tuenda, commends gold as reſtorative.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Lingua expreſſe your ſelf.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Madam if you want breath, let me help you out.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: I prethee do, do.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: My Lord, the report is, that Mercury coming late into this Country, in this very place, left a Coronet with this inſcription, that the beſt of the five ſhould have it, which the Senſes thinking to belong unto them—

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Challenge each other, and are now in arms, and 't like your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: I proteſt it likes not me.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Their battels are not far hence ready rang'd.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: O monſtrous preſumption! what ſhall we do?

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: My Lord, in your great Grandfathers time, there was I remember ſuch a breach amongſt them, therefore my Counſell is, that after his example, by the ſtrength of your authority you convent them before you.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: Lingua go preſently, command the Senſes upon their alleageance to our dread Sovereign Queen Pſyche, to diſmiſſe their companies, and perſonally to appear before me without any pretence of excuſe.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: I go my Lord.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: But hear you Madam, I pray you let your Page tongue walk with us a little, till you return again.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Hot youths I proteſt, ſaw you thoſe warlike preparations?

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.l: Lately my Lords, I ſpide into the Army,
But oh, 'tis farre beyond my reach of wit.
Or ſtrength of utterance to deſcribe their forces.

sp.speaker: COM. SENS.
sp.p: Go to, ſpeak what thou canſt.

sp.speaker: MEND
sp.l: Upon the right hand of a ſpatious Hill,
Proud Viſus marſhalleth a puiſſant Army,
Three thouſand Eagles ſtrong, whoſe valiant Captain
Is Joves fwift Thunder-bearer, that ſame Bird,
That hoiſt up Ganimede from the Trojan plains:
The vant-gard ſtrengthned with a wondrous flight
Of Falcons, Haggards, Hobbies, Terſelets,
Lanards and Goſhauks, Sparhauks, and Ravenous Birds.
The rereward granted to Anditus charge.
Is ſtoutly follow'd with an impetuous herd
Of ſtiff-neckt Buls, and many horn-mad ſtaggs,
Of the beſt head the Forreſt can afford.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: I promiſe you a fearfull troop of Souldiers

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.l: Right oppoſite ſtands Tactus ſtrongly mand,
With three thouſand briſled Urchins for his Pikemen;
Four hundred Torteſſes for Elephants.
Beſides a monſtrous troop of ugly ſpiders,
Within an ambuſhment he hath comnanded,
Of their own guts to ſpin a cordage fine,
Whereof t'have fram'd a net (O wondrous work)
That faſtned by the Concave of the Moon,
Spreads down it ſelf to th' earths circumference.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: 'Tis very ſtrange, I cannot remember the like Engine at any time.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.l: Nay more my Lord, the masks are made ſo ſtrong,
That I my ſelf upon them ſcale the heavens,
And boldly walt about the middle region,
Where in the province of the Meteors,
I ſaw the cloudy ſhops of Hail and Rain,
Garners of Snow, and Chriſtals full of dew,
Rivers of burning Arrows, Dens of Dragons,
Huge beams of flames, and Spears like fire brands,
Where I beheld hot Mars and Mercury,
With Rackets made of Sphears, and Balls of Stars,
Playing at Tennis for a Tun of Nectar.
And that vaſt gaping of the Firmament,
Under the Southern pole is nothing elſe
But the great hazzard of their Tennis Court,
The Zodiack is the line. The ſhooting Stars,
Which in an eye bright evening ſeem'd to fall,
Are nothing but the Balls they loſe at Bandy.
Thus having took my pleaſure with thoſe ſights,
By the ſame net I went up, I diſcended.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Wel Sirra to what purpoſe tends this Stratagem?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: None know directly, but I think it is
T'intrap the Eagles, when the Battails joyn.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Who takes Tactus his part?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: Under the ſtandard of thrice hardy Tactus,
Thrice valiant Guſtus leads his war-like Forces,
An endleſſe multitude of deſperate Apes,
Five hundred Marmoſets & long-tail'd Monkees:
All trained to the field, and nimble Gunners.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Imagine there's old moving amongſt them; Me thinks a handful of Nuts would turn them out of their Souldiers coats,

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.l: Ramparts of Paſty-cruſt and forts of Pies,
Entrench'd with diſhes full of Cuſtard ſtuff,
Hath Guſtus made; and planted ordinance,
Strange ordinance: Canons of hollow canes,
Whoſe powder's Rape ſeed, charged with Turnip ſhot.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.l: I remember in the Country of Utopia,
They uſe no other kind of Artillery.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: But what's become of Olfactus?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: He politickly leans to neither part,
But ſtands betwixt the camps as at receit:
Having great wine his Pioners to entrench them.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: In my fooliſh imagination Olfactus is very like the Goddeſſe of victory that never takes any part but the Conquerers.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: And in the Woods he placed ſecretly
Two hundred couple of Hounds and hungry Maſtiffs:
And ore his head hover at his command
A cloud of Vultures, which or'e ſpread the light,
Making a night before the day be done:
But to what end not known but feared of all.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: I conjecture he intends to ſee them fight, and after the battail to feed his Dogs, Hogs and Vultures upon the murdred carcaſes.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: My L. I think the fury of their anger wil not be obedient to the Meſſage of Lingua; for otherwiſe in my conceit they ſhould have been here ere this: with your L. good liking we'l attend upon you to ſee the field for more certainty. It ſhall be ſo; Come Maſter Regiſter lets walk.

div.head: Act. 3. Scena. 1.
div.stage: ANAMESTES, With a purſe in his hand.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p:
Forſooth Oblivio ſhut the door upon me, I could come no ſooner; ha? is he not there? O excellent! Would I were hang'd but I lookt for a found rap on the pate, and that made me before hand to lift up this excuſe for a Buckler. I know he's not at Court, for here's his purſe, without which warrant there's no comming thither; wherefore now Anamneſtes ſport thy ſelf a little, while thou art out of the priſon of his company. What ſhall I do? by my troth anatomize his purſe in his abſence. Plutus ſend there be Jewels in it, that I may finely geld it of the ſtones— The beſt ſure
lies in the bottome—pox out, here's nothing but a company of worm-eaten papers; what's this? Memorandum that Maſter Prodigo owes me four thouſand pounds, and that his lands are in pawn for it: Memorandum that I owe; that he owes? 'tis well the old ſlave hath ſome care of his credit; to whom owes he I trow this? that I owe Anamneſtes? What me? I never lent him any thing; ha, this is good, there's ſomething coming to me more then I look'd for. Come on, what is't? Memorandum that I owe Anamneſtes—a breeching; I faith Sir I will eaſe you of that payment, (He rends the bill) Memorandum that when I was a child, Robuſto tript up my heels at foot-ball: what a revengeful dizard's this?

div.head: ACT. 3. SCEN. 2.
div.stage: Mendatio with Cuſhions under his arms, trips up Anamneſtes heels.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: MEND
sp.p: Nothing but lay you upon the Cuſhion Sir, how ſo?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Nothing but lay the Cuſhion upon you Sir?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: What my little Nam? by this foot I am ſorry I miſtook thee.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: What my little Men? by this hand it grieves me I took thee ſo right. But Sirra whither with theſe Cuſhions?

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: To lay them here that the Judges may ſit ſoftly, leaſt my Lady Lingua's cauſe go hard with her.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: They ſhould have been wrought with gold, theſe will do nothing: But what makes thy Lady with the Judges?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Piſh, know'ſt not? ſhe ſueth for the title of a Senſe, as well as the reſt that bear the name of the Pentarchy.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Will Common ſenſe and my Maſter leave their affairs to determine that Controverſie?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Then thou hearſt nothing.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: What ſhould I hear!

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: All the Senſes fell out about a Crown faln from Heaven, and pitcht a field for it; but Vicegerent Common-ſenſe hearing of it, took upon him to umpire the contention, in which regard he hath appointed them (their armes diſmiſſed) to appear before him, charging every one to bring as it were in a ſhew their proper objects, that by them he may determine of their ſeveral excellencies.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: When is all this?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: As ſoon as they can poſſibly provide,

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: But can he tell which deſerves beſt by their objects?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: No not only; for every ſenſe muſt deſcribe his Inſtrument, that is his houſe where he performs his dayly duty, ſo that by the Object and the Inſtrument, my Lord can with great eaſe diſcern their place and dignities.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: His Lorſhip's very wiſe.

sp.speaker: MEND
sp.p:
Thou ſhalt hear all anon, fine Maſter
Phantaſtes, and thy Maſter will be here ſhortly. But how is't my little Rogue? me thinks thou look'ſt lean upon't?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Alas, how ſhould I do otherwiſe that lie all night with ſuch a Rawbon'd Skeliton as Memory, and run all day on his Errands! The Churle's grown ſo old and forgetful, that every hour he's calling Anamneſtes remembrance, where art Anamneſtes? Then preſently ſomething's loft, poor I muſt run for it; and theſe words, run Boy, Come Sirra quick, quick, quick, are as familiar with him as the Cough, never out on's mouth.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Alack, alack poor Rogue, I ſee my fortunes are better. My Lady loves me exceedingly; ſhe's always kiſſing me, ſo that (I tell the Nam) Mendacios never from betwixt her lips.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Nor out of Memories mouth; but in a worſe ſort, always exerciſing my ſtumps, and which is more, when he favours beſt, then I am in the worſt taking.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Thus, when we are friends, then muſt I come and be dandled upon his Palſie-quaking knees, and he'l tell me a long ſtory of his acquaintance with King Priamus and his familiarity with Neſtor, and how he plaid at blow-point with Jupiter when he was in his ſide-coats, and how he went to look Birds-neſts with Athon, and where he was at Deucalious ſtood, and twenty ſuch old wives tales.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: I wonder he being ſo old can talk ſo much.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Nature thou know'ſt (knowing what an unruly Engine the tongue is) hath ſet teeth round about for watchmen; Now Sir my Maſter's old age hath caught out all his teeth, and that's the cauſe it runs ſo much it liberty.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Philoſophical!

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: O but therer's one thing ſtings me to the very heart, to ſee an ugly, foul, idle, fat, duſty • log-head, called Oblivio preferred before me; doſt know him?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Who I? I▪ But care not for his acquaintance, hang him blockhead, I could never abide him. Thou Remembrance art the only friend that the arms of my friendſhip ſhall embrace. Thou haſt heard Opo • tet mendac • m eſſe memorem. But what of Oblivio?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: The very naming of him hath made me forget my ſelf. O, O, O, O, that Raſcal is ſo made of everywhere.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Who Oblivio?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: I, for our Courtiers hug him continually in their ungrateful boſomes, and your ſmooth-belly, fat-backt, barrel-pauncht, tun-gutted drones are never without him; as for Memory he's a falſe-hearted fellow, he always deceives them; they reſpect not him except it be to play a game at Cheſs, Primero, Saun • , Maw, or ſuch like.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
I cannot think ſuch fellows have to do
with Oblivio ſince they never got any thing to forget.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Again, theſe prodigal ſwaggerers that are ſo much bound to their Creditors, if they have but one Croſſe about them they'l ſpend it in wine upon Oblivio.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: To what purpoſe I prethee?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Only in hope he'l waſh them in the Lethe of their cares.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Why then no man cares for thee!

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Yes, a company of ſtudious paper-worms and lean Schollers, and niggardly ſcraping Uſurers, and a troop of heart-eating envious perſons, and thoſe cancker-ſtomackt ſpiteful creatures, that furniſh up common place-books with other mens faults. The time hath been in thoſe golden days, when Saturn reigned, that if a man received a benefit of another, I was preſently ſent for to put him in mind of it; but now in theſe Iron afternoons, ſave your friends life, and Oblivio will be more familiar with him then you.

div.head: ACTUS. 3. SCENA. 3.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: Phantaſtes not at Court? is't poſſible? 'tis the ſtrangeſt accident that ever was heard off; I had thought the Ladies and Gallants would never lie without him.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Hiſt, hiſt, Mendacio, I prethee obſerve Heureſis; it ſeems he cannot find his Maſter that's able to find out all things: and art thou now at a fault, canſt not find out thine own Maſter? no? Ile try one more way. O yes.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: What a Proclamation for him?

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: I, I, his nimble head is always full of proclamations.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: O yes.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: But doth he cry him in the wood?

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: O good Sir, and good reaſon, for every beaſt hath Phantaſie at his pleaſure.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: O yes: If any man can tell any tidings of a ſpruce, neat, apiſh, nimble, fine, fooliſh, abſurd, humerous, conceited, Phantaſtick Gallant, with hollow eyes, ſharp look, ſwart complexion, meager face, wearing as many toyes in his apparel, as fooleries in his looks and geſture, let him come forth and certifie me thereof, and he ſhall have for his reward—

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: I can tell you where he is, what ſhall he have?

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: A box o'the ear ſirra, (ſnap)

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: How now invention, are you ſo quick fingred? in faith there's your principle ſirra, (ſnap) and here's the intereſt ready in my hand (ſnap) [They fall together by the ears.] Yea? have you found out ſcratching? now I remember me.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: Do you bite you Raſcal?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, here's the lively picture of this axiome, A quick Invention and a good Memory
can never agree. Fie, fie, fie Heureſis, beat him when he's down?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Prethee lets alone, proud Jack-an-Apes, Ile▪

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: What will you do?

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: Untruſſe thy points and whip thee, thou paltry —Let me go Mendacio if thou loveſt me, ſhall I put up the—

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Come, come, come, you ſhall fight no more in good faith: Heureſis; your Maſter will catch you anon

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: My Maſter, where is he?

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Ile bring you to him, come away.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: Anamneſtes, I ſcorn that thou ſhouldſt think I go away for fear of any thing thou canſt do unto me; here's my hand as ſoon as thou canſt pick the leaſt occaſion, put up thy finger, I am for thee.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: When thou dar'ſt Heureſis, when thou dar'ſt, Ile be as ready as thy ſelf at any time.

This Heureſis, this invention, is the proudeſt Jack-an-Apes, the pearteſt ſelf-conceited Boy that ever breath'd; becauſe forſooth ſome odd Poet, or ſome ſuch Phantaſtique fellows make much on him, there's no no with him; the vile dandi-prat will ore-look the proudeſt of his acquaintance: but well I remember me, I learnt a trick t'other day, to bring a Boy ore the thigh finely; if he come, in faith Ile tickle him with it.

div.stage: Mendacio comes running back in great haſte.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p:
As I am a Raſcal Nam, they are all coming,
I ſee Maſter Regiſter trudging hither, as faſt as his three feet will carry up his four Ages.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: Ah you leaden-heel'd Raſcal.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Here 'tis Sir, I have it, I have it.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: Is this all the haſte you make?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: An't like your worſhip, your Clog-head Oblivio went before me, and foil'd the trail of your foot-ſteps, that I could hardly undertake the queſt of your purſe forſooth.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: You might have been here long ere this: Come hither ſirra, come hither, what muſt you go round about? goodly, goodly, you are full of circumſtances.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: In truth Sir, I was here before, and miſſing you, went back into the City, ſought you in every Ale-houſe, Inn, Tavern, Dicing-houſe, Tenniscourt, Stews, and ſuch like places, likely to find your worſhip in.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: Ha? villain, am I a man likely to be found in ſuch places, ha?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: No, no Sir; Sir, but I was told by my Lady Lingua's Page that your Worſhip was ſeeking me, therefore I enquired for you in thoſe places where I knew you would ask for me, and it pleaſe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: I remember another quarrel ſirra, but well, well, I have no leiſure.

div.head: ACT. 3. SCENA. 5.
div.stage: Com. Senſ. Lingua. Phantaſtes. Memory. Anamneſtes.

sp.speaker: COM. S.
sp.p: Lingua, the Senſes by our appointment anon are to preſent their objects before us; ſeeing therefore they be not in readineſſe, we licenſe you in the mean while, either in your own perſon, or by your Advocate, to ſpeak what you can for your ſelf.

sp.speaker: LIN.
sp.p: My Lord, if I ſhould bring before your honour all my friends ready to importune you in my behalf, I ſhould have ſo many Rhetoricians, Logitians, Lawyers, and which is more, ſo many women to attend me, that this Grove would hardly contain the company; wherefore to avoid the tediouſneſſe, I will lay the whole cauſe upon the tip of mine own tongue.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Be as brief as the neceſſity of our ſhort time requires.

sp.speaker: LIN.
sp.p:
My Lord, though the Imbecillitas of my feeble ſex, might draw me back from this Tribunal, with the habenis to wit Timoris, and the Catenis Pudoris; notwithſtanding being ſo fairly led on with the gracious 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 of your juſtiſſimae 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Eſpecially ſo aſpremente ſpurd' con'gli ſproni di neceſſita mia pungente, I Will without the helpe of Orators, commit the totom ſalutem of my
action to the Volutabilitati 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which (avecuoſtre bonne playſeur) I will finiſh with more then Laconicâ brevitate.

sp.speaker: CO. SE.
sp.p: Whats this? here's a Gallemaufry of ſpeech indeed.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: I remember about the yeare 1602. many uſed this skew kind of language. Which in my opinion is not much unlike the man Platony the the Sonne of Lagus, King of Aegypt, brought for a ſpectacle halfe white halfe blacke.

sp.speaker: CO. SE.
sp.p: I am perſwaded theſe ſame language-makers have the very quality of cold in their wit, that freezeth all Heterogeneall languages together, congealing Engliſh Tynne, Graecian Gold, Romane Latine all In a lumpe.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Or rather in my imagination like you Fantaſticall Gulls Apparell, wearing a Spaniſh Felt, a French Doblet, a Granado Stocking, a Dutch Slop, an Italian Cloak, with a Welch friſe Jerkin.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Well, leave your toying, we cannot pluck the leaſt feather from the ſoft wing of time. Therefore Lingua go on, but in a more formall manner; you know an ingenions Oratiō muſt neither ſwell above the Banks with inſolent words, nor creepe too ſhallow in the ford, with vulgar terms, but run equally, ſmooth, and cheerful, through the clean current of a pure ſtyle.

sp.speaker: Ling.
sp.p:
My Lord, this one thing is ſufficient to confirm my worth to be equal or better then the ſenſes, whoſe beſt operations are nothing till I poliſh
them with perfection; for their knowledge is only of things preſent, quickly ſublimed with the deaf file of time, whereas the tongue is able to recount things paſt, and often pronounce things to come, by this means re-edifying ſuch Excellencies as Time and Age do eaſily depopulate.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: But what profitable ſervice do you undertake for our dread Queen Pſyche?

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: O how I am raviſht to think how infinitely ſhe hath graced me with her moſt acceptable ſervice. But above all (which you Maſter Regiſter may well remember) when her Highneſſe taking my mouth for her inſtrument, with the Bow of my tongue ſtrucke ſo heavenly a touch upon my teeth, that ſhe charmed the very Tigers aſleep, the liſtning Bears and Lions to couch at her feet, while the Hills leaped, and the Woods danced to the ſweet harmony of her moſt Angelical accents.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: I remember it very well. Orpheus played upon the Harp, while ſhe ſang, about ſome four years after the contention betwixt Apollo and Pan, and a little before the excoriation of Marſyas.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: By the ſame token the River Alpheus, at that time purſuing his beloved Arethuſa, diſchanel'd himſelf of his former courſe to be partaker of their admirable confort, and the muſick being ended, thruſt himſelf head long into earth, the next way to follow his amorous Chaſe; if you go to Arcadia, you ſhall ſee his coming up again.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Forward Lingua with your reaſon.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: How oft hath her Excellency imployded me as Embaſſador in her moſt urgent affairs to forreign King and Emperors! I may ſay to the Gods themſelves! How many bloudleſſe Battails have my perſwaſions attained, when the ſenſes forces have been vanquiſhed.
